;;反对党工人党的支持者在后港公众挥舞党旗2020年7月新加坡大选期间的住房区。图片：法新社;
;

;据媒体报道，新加坡新任总理黄循财本周宣誓就职时在关键问题上做出了正确的表态报道称，但当他声称其强大的执政党可能会在下次选举中被赶下台时，他让许多人重新审视。

;

;在宣誓就任新加坡第四任总理之前接受当地媒体采访时部长黄说，“两个或三个反对党走到一起，组成联盟并管理政府并不是不可想象的”。

;

;黄将领导执政的人民行动党（PAP）进入大选下一次大选必须在 2025 年 11 月之前举行，但人们普遍预计会早于这一法定截止日期。

;
;;
;;新加坡新总理周三，黄循财在新加坡一个住宅区举行宣誓就职仪式后向居民挥手致意。照片：EPA-EFE;
;
;

;人民行动党赢得了共和国过去 14 次大选的全部胜利，并以绝对多数优势轻松通过宪法和其他法案。在该国立法机构的 86 名民选议员中，目前只有 8 名反对党议员，全部来自工人党 (WP)。

;

;新加坡经济今年预计增长 2.4%，并且通胀和失业率预计将基本保持不变。

;

;分析师表示，新总理关于人民行动党可能面临失去权力风险的猜测不太可能影响博彩公司。

;

;相反，这是人民行动党标准剧本的一部分，警告选民不要将稳定、有能力的政府视为理所当然——他们对更多反对声音的渴望可能会导致所谓的“反常选举”，将新加坡的未来置于能力较弱的政客手中.

;

;作为未经民意调查考验的新总理，黄之锋个人也有兴趣降低期望。即使反对派如许多人所期望的那样增加其选票份额和议会席位，黄也需要宣布这一结果对他和他的团队来说是一项响亮的授权。

;

;黄在采访中说：“如果你是不仅是工人党，还有其他一两个反对党，如果下次选举竞争更加激烈，我们只损失几个百分点，那么两个或三个反对党联合起来，组成一个联盟，也不是不可想象的。组建联合政府并管理政府。”

;

;“[对他们来说]获得超过 50% 的选票，一点也不难以想象。这就是为什么当我说我不认为人民行动党会赢得下一次选举或我会在选举后自动成为总理时，我是认真地说的。这就是我们今天政治局势的现实。它不再是一个占主导地位的系统，一党制，”他说。

;
;;
;;人们聚集在一起聆听新加坡总理李显龙的演讲执政党人民行动党的显龙在 2015 年 9 月大选前的一次集会上向午餐人群发表演讲。照片：法新社;
;
;

;前报纸编辑伯莎·汉森(Bertha Henson)周三在脸书上发帖表示：“这当然并非不可想象，这反映了评论家的怀疑。一切皆有可能，但有可能吗？”

;

;小型反对党进步新加坡党的发言人反驳说，没有反对党议员当选进入国会的可能性“微乎其微”。比黄所描述的更有可能出现的情况。

;

;关于联合政府的前景，他说：“[这]需要公众舆论发生巨大转变才能实现。”

;

;黄周三接替担任总理二十年的李显龙，成为政府首脑。李光耀仍留在黄之锋内阁担任高级部长。

;

;人民行动党连续执政 65 年，是实行竞争性选举的国家历史上执政时间第二长的政党，仅次于墨西哥革命制度党。从 1929 年到 2000 年，它领导了 71 年。人民行动党看起来几乎肯定会打破革命制度党的记录。

;

;自 1965 年独立以来，人民行动党的全国选票比例从未低于 60%。尽管反对派并呼吁在体制中加强制衡，但大多数新加坡人并不希望人民行动党下台。

;
;
;

;“即使反对派也知道这种情况发生的想法会澳大利亚谢里登高等教育学院政治与传播学教授特伦斯·李（Terence Lee）表示：“恐吓选民，让人民行动党重新掌权。”

;

;反对派试图安抚选民，称其近期目标是温和的。

;

;工人党如此急于避免用非人民行动党政府的幽灵来吓唬潜在的摇摆选民，以至于其领导人普里塔姆·辛格（Pritam Singh）斥责了一位政治学家，后者在上个月的《海峡时报》评论中错误地声称，工人党正在寻求“在下次大选中组建政府”。该分析师就这一错误向辛格道歉。

;

;“也许有一种观点认为，这种言论会导致摇摆选民转向保守派并投票给人民行动党，”辛格在社交媒体帖子中写道。 “工人党多年来一直对其选举议程持开放态度。中期目标是发挥我们的作用，确保至少三分之一的议会席位不落入人民行动党手中。”

;

;他写道，这将有助于建立“更平衡的政治体系”。 “像许多新加坡人一样，工人党寻求的是我们政治制度的演变，而不是革命。”

;
;;
;;工人党主席 Pritam Singh试图消除该党希望组建政府的传言。照片：路透社;
;
;

;新加坡三个较大的反对党——工人党、新加坡民主党 (SDP) 和新加坡进步党——分别在《亚洲周刊》上发表讲话，拒绝了黄的建议修辞。工人党发言人表示，此举“旨在引导选民走向熟悉的道路”，并指出人民行动党的主导地位“自新加坡独立以来就已根深蒂固”。

;

;“重要的是要重申，人民行动党的政治立场发言人在回答问题时表示，自新加坡独立以来，新加坡的主导地位一直牢牢巩固，从未失去议会绝对多数，更不用说受到对政府控制权的挑战。

;

;目前，当选的反对党议员93个可用选举席位中的席位不到10%，其中包括排名第二的非选区席位。 WP 发言人强调，这需要“数十年的艰苦牺牲和坚持不懈的努力”。

;
;;
;;新加坡反对党领袖 Pritam Singh 和时任总理李显龙在疫情期间。照片：Facebook;
;
;

;新加坡医生、44 岁的新加坡民主党主席 Paul Tambyah 将反对派联盟执政的可能性描述为“非常牵强” .

;

;“其他政党都没有当选议员。要从这一点转变为工作多数，需要非常生动的想象力，这对大多数新加坡人来说是陌生的。”他说，并强调，由于执政党背后庞大的政治机制，另类政党的“可能性很大”。

;

;他列举了人民协会——管理着100多个社区俱乐部和草根组织——与共产党有着密切的联系，表明法定委员会可以作为共产党传播影响力的另一个平台。

;
;;
;;新加坡民主党的 Paul Tambyah 博士在 2015 年 9 月的一次党夜集会上。照片：Getty Images;
;;
;;

;政府此前曾反驳这些指控，称“它为当今政府服务”，并且“不允许任何政党将其活动或场地用于党派目的，并为所有新加坡人服务，无论他们的国籍如何”在去年 5 月的议会答复中，“政治倾向”。

;

;但唐纳德·洛 (Donald Low) 表示，任何现任政府都会“利用其拥有的一切资源和工具来限制反对党的利益”，香港科技大学公共政策教授。

;

;“人民行动党执政已很长时间，因此执政优势根深蒂固。”

;
;< img src="https://cdn.i-scmp.com/sites/default/files/d8/images/canvas/2024/05/17/6509a633-51c9-41ca-84b0-cba43803a35e_798e21ed.jpg" alt="" >;
;;2020 年 7 月 10 日大选期间，选民在新加坡投票站排队投票。照片：EPA-EFE;
;
;

;新加坡选举地图由单议席和多议席选区组成，政府称其目的是为了提高种族代表性，但被广泛视为提高小党派进入门槛的一种手段。< /p>;

;“集选区制度也为反对党提高竞争力设置了障碍，并放大了新加坡政治制度的多数主义倾向。”刘特佐指出。

;

;反对派于 2011 年赢得了首个集选区，并于 2020 年赢得了第二个集选区。这些结果促使人民行动党的坚定支持者试图打造这样一种说法：人民行动党这些曾经坚不可摧的选举堡垒现在更具争议性，声称反对党以他们所描述的总体上不公平的竞争环境为由拒绝了这一说法。

;

;正是从这种脆弱的逻辑出发，黄的设想才具有可信度，一位不愿透露姓名的人民行动党基层领导人表示。 。 “从数学上看，这并非不可能。如果再有几个 GRC 倒塌，这种情况就有可能发生。称其为恐吓策略或其他什么，但我们必须认真对待，投票可以进行，”他说。

;

;但严酷的现实超出了政治机制的问题，新加坡选民还没有准备好或不愿意当执政党基本实现目标时，组建一个非人民行动党政府。观察人士表示，尽管对某些政策存在争议或不满，但久经考验的新加坡模式仍然有效。

;
;;
;;时任总理李显在 2020 年 7 月新加坡大选之前，现任人民行动党的 Loong（上中）在购物中心的食品摊贩面前与一位老妇人交谈。照片：EPA-EFE;
;
;

;虽然在不久的将来不太可能出现反对派联盟执政的情况，但反对党否认人民行动党获得三分之二多数的“更合理但仍然不太可能的情况”仍然取决于许多因素，刘特佐表示。

;

;“如果这种情况成为现实，人民行动党面临的问题是它是否有足够的板凳实力来组建一个强大、有能力的内阁。对于反对党来说，如果要拒绝人民行动党获得三分之二多数，问题是他们能否组建一个可信的影子内阁。”

;

;虽然议会仍然是人民行动党的大本营，但执政党的份额的民众投票被认为更容易受到影响。全国得票率被广泛视为人民行动党支持率的晴雨表。

;

;考虑到自 1965 年独立以来，全国得票率从未低于 60%，黄不希望这一心理障碍被打破。在他作为总理的第一次选举中，即使它没有宪法影响。

;

;在 2020 年选举中，人民行动党获得了 61.24% 的普选票。然而，在与工人党的正面竞争中，执政党仅在一个选区超过了 60% 的支持率。

;

;为了回应新加坡人希望人民行动党政府不那么占主导地位的愿望，黄说，他打算采取更加“开放、协商”的领导风格。

;

;政治学家特伦斯·李 (Terence Lee) 对此并不以为然。 “前两位前总理吴作栋和李显龙在上任时都发表过类似的声明。公平地说，他们的成果很小，但对新加坡人来说还远远不够。”

;

;人民行动党已经认识到需要倾听基层意见并制​​定能够赢得大多数人支持的政策分析人士表示，尽管做出了艰难的决定，但现在王必须做得更多。

;

;“劳伦斯·王强调他会进行更多咨询是有道理的，但证据就在布丁，新加坡人将对此做出判断，尤其是在投票箱中，”这位澳大利亚分析师表示。

;
;;
;;新加坡黄循财与支持者合影。图片来源：Facebook/Lawrence Wong;
;
;

;为了减缓反对派的壮大，人民行动党除了限制“利用唐纳德·洛 (Donald Low) 表示，“将国家的镇压工具降到最低限度”。

;

;“如果公民没有看到国家对政治对手使用大棒，那么他们就没有理由投票给弱势群体。它的批评者，”他说。 “此外，当公民可以自由参与和批评时，他们会发现议会并不是唯一可以进行此类辩论的机构。”

;

;下一次大选将在全球不确定性的背景下举行或者正如黄所描述的那样，这是一个“更加混乱、更加危险、更加暴力的世界”。人民行动党在这种时期往往表现良好，分析师此前将其立场描述为“逃往安全地带”。然而，在国内，生活成本上升、工作不确定性以及对外国人才挥之不去的怀疑都可能拖累其发展。

; Sun, 19 May 2024 08:20:01 +0800 How Hong Kong’s Mai Po wetlands are under threat again, and past battles the ‘bird paradise’ has facedhttps://www.scmp.com/magazines/post-magazine/long-reads/article/3263099/how-hong-kongs-mai-po-wetlands-are-under-threat-again-and-past-battles-bird-paradise-has-faced?utm_source=rss_feed

;;
;;2018 年 3 月，白嘴鳄在香港米埔上空飞行照片：Martin Williams;
;

;冬日涨潮时，数以千计的水鸟聚集在日益缩小的裸露泥滩上。成群的鹬和其他滨鸟、黑白反嘴鹬、白鹭、苍鹭和琵鹭。海鸥聚集在海岸线上，远处的浅滩上也聚集着成群的鸭子。

;

;空中响起鸟儿的鸣叫声和颤音，然后是游隼猛冲而来的惊叫声和突然猛烈的拍打翅膀。进入它们的中间，驱散了羊群，并让公寓短暂空置。

;

;即使您没有特殊许可证来参观米埔沼泽的这个隐蔽处，您仍然可以在附近欣赏鸟类生活鱼塘区域。

;

;鸟群规模较小，最多可能有数十只鸟，但您可以与灰鹭、小白鹭、普通水鸭等物种近距离接触 -这些精致的鸭子的红褐色头上有绿色斑点，还有黑色翅膀的高跷，因其非常长的腿而得名。

;
;;
;;米埔湿地的反嘴鳄。照片：Martin Williams;
;
;

;慢慢移动，您可能会看到这些鸟儿进食、梳理毛发，甚至打瞌睡。但任何突然的动作，它们都会迅速飞走：提醒人们，它们的生命充满危险，其中人类是最大的危险。

;

;在香港，鸟类没有被猎杀，但仍然面临许多问题，包括他们称之为家的地方遭到破坏，无论是全年，还是在移民来访的季节，也许是为了长期停留。

;

;泥滩、红树林和鱼塘都在湿地内后海湾的综合体，实际上很浅，只是在香港和深圳共有的海岸上留下了一个深深的凹痕。

;

;在世界范围内，像后海湾这样的滩涂长期以来一直受到人类的改造，特别是为农业、水产养殖和定居点创造新的土地。

;

;澳大利亚昆士兰大学和詹姆斯库克大学的研究人员最近进行了一项题为“全球保护区覆盖范围和人类对潮滩的压力”的研究，据估计，1984 年至 2016 年间，全球有 16% 的滩涂消失，其中东亚的变化尤其明显。

;

;对珠江三角洲的评估发现，在过去的半个世纪里，滩涂的长度自然海岸线长度从 136.91 公里（85 英里）骤减至 15.17 公里，填海面积约为 282 平方公里（109 平方英里），相当于香港陆地总面积的四分之一。

;
;;
;;新田的鱼塘。政府计划毁掉大片鱼塘，以兴建新田科技城的一部分。照片：Martin Williams;
;
;

;后海湾能够幸存下来真是一个奇迹。新界的边界将该地区一分为二，使南岸成为香港乡村腹地的一部分，这无疑有帮助。

;

;自20世纪70年代以来，发展压力加剧，而后海湾的部分地区受到保护尤其是在米埔沼泽地，保育措施往往缺乏雄心，甚至近乎胆怯。

;

;现在，政府计划毁掉大片鱼塘以兴建新田科技城的一部分，而同时新保护区的承诺和其他开发项目的出现，使 2024 年成为后海湾历史上的关键。

;
;;
;;鸬鹚飞过深圳，看到来自凤乐围鱼塘。图片：Martin Williams;
;
;

;在《东南亚地理与环境》论文集1978年的一篇文章中，作者黎传彦指出，大约1957 年，海湾的一半被矮小的红树林和盐沼覆盖，但 20 世纪 50 年代也开始对这些地区进行大规模的填海造地。种植抗性水稻，饲养鸭子和家禽，还有鱼塘和基围——涨潮时可以注水，退潮时可以清空以捕虾。到1969年，基围和鱼塘几乎覆盖了总面积的一半。

;

;许多水鸟喜欢新池塘，尤其是米埔的基围，英国著名自然保育人士也曾到访Peter Scott 于 1946 年建立了野禽信托基金，并于 1961 年成为世界自然基金会 (WWF) 的主要创始人。

;
;;
;;从新田鱼塘看到的黑翅长脚鹬。图片：Martin Williams;
;
;

;斯科特建议在米埔建立保护区，1968年政府成立的乡村利用及保育临时委员会也响应了这一想法。< /p>;

;“当地环保人士对 1975 年 3 月 16 日的报纸报道感到惊讶，该报道称政府已基本批准加拿大海外开发公司 (CODC) 在太湖开发 116 公顷养鱼场。赖在 1978 年的文章中指出：“上围（毗邻米埔）变成了一个可容纳约 30,000 人的大型住宅区。”

;

;回顾 1990 年的案例，时任世界自然基金会香港分会的自然保护主任 David梅尔维尔说道：“这是一个开始衰退的时期——此后出现了很多新的发展。”

;

;然而，正如梅尔维尔所说，“香港观鸟协会的两名成员、迈克·韦伯斯特和弗雷德·赫希特尔向政府请愿，要求采取某种保护措施。

;

;“如果没有他们的行动，我们可能会失去米埔，它被宣布为具有特殊科学价值的地点。这提高了规划者对地方重要性的认识。”

;

;住房项目继续进行，成为锦绣花园的高档郊区，并在此过程中摧毁了香港最后的雉尾水雉筑巢地一只英俊的百合花。

;

;此外，1982年，政府批准了新成立的世界自然基金会香港分会的请求，在米埔建立自然保护区。两年后，保护区正式成立，次年世界自然基金会香港分会开始筹建米埔沼泽野生动物教育中心及自然保护区。

;
;;
;;1989 年，虾农在米埔捕鱼，当时虾农仍拥有部分池塘权利。摄影：Martin Williams;
;
;

;“米埔”几乎成了后海湾湿地的代名词。早年的变化包括一条木板路穿过邻近的红树林到达泥滩，在那里，可以在海湾中心看到前所未有的鸟类景观。

;

;得益于此，加上由两个基围合并而成的泻湖鸟类观测有所增加，经常看到勺嘴鹬等全球稀有物种，使米埔在世界各地的观鸟者中享有盛誉。

;

;鹬是观鸟者的鸟类，通常是上体灰色，下体白色，体型稍大。麻雀，因是唯一一种嘴尖扁平的滨鸟而闻名。然而，很快，出现了一种具有更广泛吸引力的星鸟，它的喙也是勺形的。

;

;自 20 世纪 50 年代以来，黑脸琵鹭在冬季就经常出现，尽管这种鸟仅限于东亚它们几乎被认为是理所当然的，直到热门观鸟者 Peter Kennerley 注意到有关它们的信息匮乏，并发出了目击请求。

;
;;
;;黑脸琵鹭在米埔上空飞翔。照片：Martin Williams;
;
;

;1990 年，他公布了他能计算出的全世界人口的最佳总数：288 只。突然之间，黑脸琵鹭有了令人怀疑的区别：被列为极度濒危物种，在东北亚繁殖，只有三个主要冬季栖息地：台湾、越南各一个，以及后海湾。

;

;身高约 75 厘米，形状像一只粗壮的白鹭。凭借匙形喙，琵鹭成为旗舰物种，在有关后海湾和米埔的媒体文章中出现。

;

;很大程度上，由于该海湾养育了大量这种水鸟和其他迁徙水鸟，因此它有资格被列为联合国《拉姆萨尔公约》规定的具有国际重要性的湿地。

;

;经过梅尔维尔等人多年的游说，政府同意申请列入名录，并于 1995 年成为拉姆萨尔湿地，最初是通过英国政府，并从 1997 年起通过中国政府。

;
;;
;;新田电线上的大鸬鹚和牛背鹭。图片：Martin Williams;
;
;

;为了保护拉姆萨尔湿地，并实现公约所要求的“明智利用”湿地，香港政府设立了从到那时，已经来不及挽救园附近约5平方公里的鱼塘和农田了。长的。这片土地是由名字令人印象深刻、现已不复存在的 Mightycity 公司买下的，该公司在 20 世纪 80 年代开始用沙子和瓦砾覆盖该地区，用于建设天水围新市镇。

;

;意外地，水池和草地填海区的湿地吸引了多种鸟类，政府于1998年决定兴建香港湿地公园，以减轻鸟类的损失。

;

;随着2000年的临近，湿地公园逐渐演变成政府的重点公园之一千禧年计划，涉及旅游事务署和渔农自然护理署。

;

;到 2006 年开业时，已斥资约 5 亿港元建设设施，包括设有步行道的大型游客中心- 北极立体模型配有驯鹿标本、印度鳄鱼在真人大小的红树林复制品中游泳的展览，以及带有移动座椅的 3D 剧院（新展览的工作正在进行中，与当地湿地更加相关）。

;

;在外面，水被从人工瀑布抽到几乎无菌的淡水区域；公园的尽头有一个潮汐泻湖，成为鸟类唯一的好去处，但只占公园面积不到百分之十，与米埔相比显得黯然失色。

;

;同时，腐烂仍在继续。随着红树林的蔓延，后海湾本身也发生了变化，滩涂水位上升，当深圳河被拉直以减轻洪水风险时，更多的淤泥到达。

;

;总体结果是鸟类栖息的滩涂面积减少。可以喂食。村屋、废品场、车辆修理场、卡车停车场和前田地里堆放着六层高的集装箱，周围环绕着鱼塘，由于商业挑战和未来的不确定性，其中许多鱼塘已被废弃。

;

;这些不确定性的部分原因是发展商以营利为目的，购买大大小小的鱼塘区。

;

;20世纪90年代初，恒基兆业地产计划在米埔附近兴建带有高尔夫球场的新城住宅区。< /p>;

;世界自然基金会香港分会最初表示支持，特别是因为开发商计划通过将一片鱼塘恢复为红树林和沼泽来创建一个自然保护区，但后来加入了一个反对该计划的联盟——因为人们越来越认识到鱼类池塘对野生动物很重要，加上政府更好地执行保护它们的法规。

;

;法庭案件接踵而至，桑尼维尔最终到达高等法院，然后被叫停。然而，亨德森似乎开创了先例，因为其他鱼塘区域也宣布了类似的计划，同样承诺通过美化和管理附近其他鱼塘来补偿一些鱼塘被破坏的情况，从而吸引更多野生动物。

;

;环保人士对这些好处持怀疑态度，更宏伟的计划被搁置。

;

;其中之一是世界自然基金会香港分会和长江实业之间的合作，旨在在鱼塘区的部分区域建造住房凤乐围的项目 – 直到 2013 年世界自然基金会香港分会退出合作伙伴关系后才停止，而 Green Sense 于次年寻求司法复核，导致城市规划委员会在六年后重新考虑该申请。

;

;这些统计结果促使香港中文大学和英国埃塞克斯大学的研究人员发表了2023 年 9 月发表的一篇论文，题为“鸟类绿洲的兴衰：追踪世界最大特大城市关键沿海湿地土地利用变化的影响”，指出污染和开垦是鸭子等鸟类数量减少的关键原因。海鸥。

;

;2023 年 11 月，世界自然基金会赛马会米埔彼得史考特游客中心开幕，这座建筑正如其名，相当宏伟，有点像一座城市博物馆，但里面没什么可看的，而且游客数量也不少严格限制。

;

;Just how much would you pay for a chocolate-filled pineapple bun in Hong Kong?

;

;That very Hong Kong question has triggered intense debate among residents online after single pineapple buns and egg tarts, both with filling, were being sold for HK$48 – later lowered to HK$45 – and HK$30, respectively, at a weekend festival in Causeway Bay.

;

;“It still looks like an ordinary pineapple bun no matter how I see it,” one sceptical commenter said on the Reddit-like LIHKG forum.

;

;“It is not an ordinary pineapple bun – it's a very expensive pineapple bun,” another wrote.

;

;But Tai On Coffee & Tea Shop, which ran the stall, defended the pricing of their premium-range products which are a twist on the traditional version, noting that its egg tarts included unique flavours such as Hong Kong-style milk tea and taro coconut milk with sago, while its pineapple buns were filled with matcha chocolate or white chocolate.

;

;Another staff member at the stall said there was a misunderstanding on Friday as people took pictures of a price tag displayed next to a plain bun on the cabinet, but in fact they would only add the fresh fillings after receiving an order.

;

;The Post observed that the price tag had already been removed on Saturday.

;

;Responding to online comments, the shop said their ingredients were imported from overseas with high costs and the pastries were handmade without machines.

;

;“We used matcha powder of high quality from Japan, and white chocolate from French brand Valrhona,” confectioner Hedis Fok said. “We also take steps to make sure the chocolate is smooth and put whiskey in the white chocolate, which adds layers to the taste.”

;
;;
;;Confectioner Hedis Fok puts the finishing touches on one of the pineapple buns. Photo: Sammy Heung;
;
;

;They expected to sell 200 egg tarts and 36 pineapple buns per day, she added.

;

;Staff also said the pricing of the pastries was similar to what was found at their physical shop in Yau Ma Tei, which is a mix between a cha chaan teng and a cafe.

;

;The Urban Jam Festival, organised by the Lee Gardens Association, brought together around 50 businesses including Tai On, vintage clothing shops, barbershops and tattoo artists with stalls set up along Kai Chiu Road, Yun Ping Road and Pak Sha Road in Causeway Bay.

;

;Yvonne Ma, 40, who works in the marketing sector, said it was the best weekend market she had seen since the reopening of the mainland China border with Hong Kong following the pandemic, lauding its lively atmosphere and the thoughtful choices of businesses.

;

;“For other weekend markets, the shops can be commonly seen across the city,” she said.

;

;“At this festival, the businesses we see here are start-ups of great quality, but which may not have the ability to rent a retail space at a good location.”

;

;Ma said the pricing of the food was “reasonable” as it was comparable to other weekend markets in the United Kingdom or United States.

;

;“I think it is not just about shopping, but to chat with creators in Hong Kong, which I enjoyed the most,” she said.

;

;The festival will be held during the two weekends from May 17 to 19 and May 25 to 26. It is also one of the events under the government's “Day x Night Vibes @ 18 Districts” initiative to promote the distinctness of the city's neighbourhoods.

;

;Brain Wong, a 30 year-old retail worker, said it had been a long time since he saw such a big crowd on the streets.

;

;“There are many eye-catching elements such as tattoos and barbershops,” he said. “They make the festival more carnivallike, unlike the other markets that only have food and dried goods.”

;

;Alison Lau, a 24-year-old clerk from Guangzhou, said it was worth visiting the festival but it was not so different from those organised on the mainland.

;

;She said the HK$45 pineapple bun was out of her budget.

; Sun, 19 May 2024 00:50:01 +0800 Why are Hong Kong taxi drivers going ‘undercover’ to target Uber and what’s behind their latest clash?https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/transport/article/3263221/why-are-hong-kong-taxi-drivers-going-undercover-target-uber-and-whats-behind-their-latest-clash?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2024.05.18 23:40;
;;
;;Some customers say taxi drivers complain about, or even refuse to go to, destinations that they feel are too close. Photo: May Tse;
;

;A new wave of tension between Hong Kong taxi and Uber drivers has erupted in the past week, with cabbies mounting their own “undercover” operations to report illegal ride-hailing services to police.

;

;The Post unpacks the latest developments, as well as the history of troubles between Uber and the city's taxi industry.

;

;1. What's the latest conflict about?

;

;Taxi drivers launched an “undercover operation” this month by posing as Uber passengers and asking their drivers to stop at places where they had called police.

;

;Purportedly led by the Hong Kong Taxi Council, the “agents” filmed their car rides to places such as the Kai Tak Cruise Terminal and posted them on social media. Seven cases had been reported on Thursday alone and six more on Saturday, according to industry representatives.

;

;In return, calls by internet users to take retaliatory action gained momentum ahead of the weekend on forums such as Facebook and the Reddit-like LIHKG.

;

;Suggestions included reporting every illegally parked taxi seen on the street, or deploying tactics to inconvenience taxi drivers such as asking for exact change for fares.

;

;2. Is Uber illegal in Hong Kong?

;

;Uber has been operating in Hong Kong since 2014 but its legal status has long been in question due to the city's lack of legislation solely for the regulation of ride-hailing apps.

;

;But generally, it is against the law for private vehicles to accept customers without a hire-car permit from the Transport Department.

;

;First violations incur a maximum penalty of a HK$10,000 fine and six months in prison, while subsequent convictions can lead to one year in jail and a fine of HK$25,000.

;

;Uber does not regulate its drivers over the use of permits.

;

;In one case in 2018, two men who were hoping to become drivers on the platform had their permit applications rejected by the commissioner for transport.

;

;Two years later, 24 Uber drivers who were found guilty of carrying passengers for hire or reward lost their last-ditch appeals to Hong Kong's top court. The case stemmed from the conviction of 28 drivers, the largest group so far, who were fined between HK$3,000 and HK$4,500 in 2018.

;

;In matters of insurance, while the company has bought a Motor Vehicles Insurance (Third Party Risks) Ordinance for all of its drivers, the lingering legal doubts have also brought into question the legitimacy of its insurance coverage.

;
;;
;;Some of the cars of Uber drivers targeted by cabbies in their “undercover” operation. Photo: Bosco Chu;
;
;

;3. Why are taxi drivers so upset?

;

;A number of events have put the battle between taxis and Uber in the spotlight recently.

;

;They include a government proposal to introduce stiffer penalties on unlicensed drivers, the details of which were expected to be announced as soon as next month.

;

;Ng Kwan-sing, vice-chairman of Hong Kong Taxi Council, also complained of the government's lack of action against Uber.

;

;“Why can't authorities just come out and crack down hard on Uber, since they have already said it is illegal?” he said.

;

;“Some people are even saying, if the government really wanted to fix things, they wouldn't be acting so soft.”

;

;The Executive Council also approved earlier this week a HK$2 (25 US cents) rise in flag-fall rates for taxi trips.

;

;According to the chairman of the Hong Kong Taxi and Public Light Bus Association, Chau Kwok-keung, the latest developments saw some online users “sending hate” to the taxi industry, sparking immense frustrations among drivers especially at a time when they were still struggling to recover from the pandemic and compete with “illegal services”.

;

;4. Why is Uber still popular?

;

;Despite legal issues, Uber remains a popular mode of transport for Hongkongers.

;

;Customers have said they prefer Uber for the convenience, safety and better service, with electronic payment on offer.

;

;Some noted taxi drivers would also complain about, or even refuse to go to, destinations that they felt were too close, or found ways to overcharge passengers.

;

;Stories by tourists on social media platforms, such as the popular mainland Chinese platform Xiaohongshu, about taxi drivers speeding recklessly, claiming exorbitant extra fees from visitors and being rude have also fuelled the narrative of bad service.

;
;;
;;Uber has been operating in Hong Kong since 2014. Photo: Shuttersock;
;
;

;5. How do other jurisdictions handle it?

;

;Many other places have been through teething issues with their local taxi industries when ride-hailing apps such as Uber were first introduced.

;

;In Singapore, basic regulatory frameworks were introduced as early as 2014 after Uber entered its market the previous year.

;

;While Uber has retreated from Southeast Asia since 2018, similar platforms such as Grab are fully legal, with the requirement that non-taxi drivers obtain a Private Hire Car Driver's Vocational Licence.

;

;Over in Taiwan, Uber also went through years of obstructions by the taxi industry with the government caught in between, before authorities in 2019 finally laid out clear regulations dubbed the “Uber clause”, defining the difference between vehicle rental services and taxis, and ensuring drivers adhered to relevant laws.

;

;6. What has the government done to resolve the conflicts?

;

;To tackle accusations of bad service, the government proposed a bill to introduce premium taxi fleets promising higher quality services, which was passed by the Legislative Council in December.

;

;Operations have also been conducted to tackle overcharging, especially towards tourists and those travelling to and from higher-risk places such as entertainment district Lan Kwai Fong.

;

;A citywide taxi strike was avoided in November after industry representatives said authorities gave promises of a crackdown on unlicensed ride-hailing services, with a government proposal to introduce stricter penalties on unlicensed drivers expected later this year.

;Lawmakers dragged their feet for months and only passed the law in mid-April, a week after Ukraine lowered the age for men who can be drafted from 27 to 25. The measures reflect the growing strain that more than two years of war with Russia has had on Ukraine's forces, who are trying to hold the front lines in fighting that has sapped the country's ranks and stores of weapons and ammunition.

;

;Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky also signed two other laws on Friday, allowing prisoners to join the army and increasing fines for draft dodgers fivefold. Russia enlisted its prisoners early on in the war, and personnel shortages forced Ukraine to adopt the new, controversial measures.

;Oleksii, 68, who runs a car repair shop in Kyiv, worries his business will have to shut down as he expects 70 per cent of his workers will be mobilised. He asked that only his first name be used to allow him to speak freely.

;

;“With the new law, people will be mobilised and we will have to shut down and stop paying taxes,” Oleksii said on Saturday.

;

;It's very difficult to replace workers because of their specialised skills. Most of them are already in the armed forces, he says, adding that the law is “unfair” and “unclear”.

;

;He said 60 of the 220 people working in Kaminsky's department will be eligible to be called up. “If they take 30 people from what we have, the problem is we don't have anyone to replace them,” he said.

;

;“There are pros and cons to this law,” Kaminsky said. “与以前人们试图绕过这一过程相比，现在很难避免动员过程。” But, he said, it would be better if essential workers like his were granted more exemptions.

;Ukraine has struggled for months to replenish depleted forces, as Russian troops are pushing ahead with a ground offensive that opened a new front in the northeast and put further pressure on Kyiv's overstretched military.

;

;After weeks of probing, Moscow launched the new push knowing that Ukraine suffered personnel shortages , and that its forces have been spread thin in the northeastern Kharkiv region.

;

;Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Friday during a visit to China that the Russian push aims to create a “buffer zone” rather than capturing Kharkiv , the local capital and Ukraine's second-largest city.

;

;Still, Moscow's forces have pummelled Kharkiv with strikes in recent weeks, hitting civilian and energy infrastructure and prompting angry accusations from Volodymyr Zelensky that the Russian leadership sought to reduce城市化为废墟。 On Friday, Mayor Ihor Terekhov said that Russian guided bombs killed at least three residents and injured 28 others that day.

;

;Moscow denies deliberately targeting civilians, but thousands have died or suffered injuries in the more than 27 months of fighting.

;

;The US last week announced a new US$400 million package of military aid for Ukraine, and President Joe Biden has promised that he would rush badly needed weaponry to the country to help it stave off Russian advances. Still, only small batches of US military aid have started to trickle into the front line, according to Ukrainian military commanders, who said it will take at least two months before supplies meet Kyiv's needs to hold the line.

;Many Ukrainians have fled the country to avoid the draft since Russia's all-out invasion in February 2022.

;The Supreme Court last month said that 930 people were convicted of avoiding mobilisation last year, a fivefold increase from 2022.

;Around 768,000 Ukrainian men aged 18-64 had been granted temporary protection in European Union countries as of last November, according to data from the bloc's statistical agency, Eurostat.

;

;Kyiv has barred men under 60 from leaving the country since the start of the war, but some are exempt, including those who are disabled or have three or more children. The Eurostat data does not specify how many of the men who have qualified for protection belong to these categories, nor how many others reached the EU from Ukraine's Russian-occupied territories in the east and south.

;

;Unable to cross the border legally, some Ukrainian men risk death trying to swim across a river that separates Ukraine from neighbouring Romania and Hungary.

;

;Late on Friday, Ukraine's border service said that at least 30 people have died trying to cross the Tisza River since the full scale-invasion.
